physical_appearance:This is the British Army uniform that consists of a coat
 pants
 sash
 and hat. The coat has gold accents; the cuffs and collar are embroidered with gold bullion in oak leaf motif
 whilst brass buttons have been sewn on.  On the other hand
 the trousers are black with a gold braid stripe running down the side of each leg.  The gold braid can also be found on the hat which has an accompanying elastic sweatband. Also in a matching colour tone is the red and gold sash with tussles.

sgcool_label_text:The British Army uniform
 sometimes referred to as “redcoat”
 has grown to become a symbol of the British Empire. Versions were widely worn within the colonies of the British Empire
 by the British
 Indians
 and other Imperial soldiers. Today it is used as a ceremonial dress for the armies of many countries previously under British rule.\r\nThis particular uniform may have belonged to General A. W. Thorneycroft
 known for his contributions to the Battle of Spion Kop during the Second Boer War. \r\n

metadata.title_text: British military uniform components: coat, pants, sash, hat
metadata.physical_appearance: This is the British Army uniform that consists of a coat, pants, sash, and hat. The coat has gold accents; the cuffs and collar are embroidered with gold bullion in oak leaf motif, whilst brass buttons have been sewn on.  On the other hand, the trousers are black with a gold braid stripe running down the side of each leg.  The gold braid can also be found on the hat which has an accompanying elastic sweatband. Also in a matching colour tone is the red and gold sash with tussles.
metadata.subject_terms_1: insignia (devices)  coats (garments) trousers sashes (costume accessories)  hats rank
metadata.subject_terms_2: Great Britain. Army Great Britain Colonies Coats Pants Felt hats  Insignia  South African War, 1899-1902 military uniforms
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The British Army uniform, sometimes referred to as “redcoat”, has grown to become a symbol of the British Empire. Versions were widely worn within the colonies of the British Empire, by the British, Indians, and other Imperial soldiers. Today it is used as a ceremonial dress for the armies of many countries previously under British rule.
This particular uniform may have belonged to General A. W. Thorneycroft, known for his contributions to the Battle of Spion Kop during the Second Boer War.
